awd_titl_txt: The Mathematical Education of Teachers as an Application of Undergraduate Mathematics (META Math)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create textbook-independent, college mathematics modules aligned with recommendations from the Conference Board of the Mathematical Sciences 2012 report titled, "The Mathematical Education of Teachers II." Specifically, each module will present the teaching of secondary level mathematics as an application of a traditional, undergraduate mathematics major course. These materials will raise the application of teaching secondary-level mathematics to parallel traditional application areas such as engineering, physics, economics, and life sciences, which have always been featured in college mathematics. The modules developed by this project will be classroom tested and evaluated to provide feedback for improvement as well as for creating a blueprint for additional future module development in all mathematics major courses.

This project will increase faculty capacity to guide undergraduate pre-service teachers in (i) making explicit connections between undergraduate mathematics and the school mathematics they will teach, and (ii) developing sophisticated understanding of mathematics taught in grades 7-12. The specific objectives of this project are to (i) develop quality instructional modules that make explicit connections between college mathematics and school mathematics; (ii) pilot test these materials; and (iii) research student learning that results from the use of these modules and evaluate the effectiveness of the process created to develop the modules. This project will also provide insight into the impact of module usage on a faculty member's own understanding of school mathematics content from an advanced perspective. The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program is providing co-funding for this project in recognition of its alignment with the broader teacher preparation goals of the Noyce effort.

por.por_cntn:
From the outset of the META Math project we have focused on two broad goals: increasing mathematics instructors? capacity to guide prospective secondary mathematics teachers in (i) making explicit connections between undergraduate mathematics and the school mathematics they will teach, and (ii) developing deep, sophisticated understanding of mathematics taught in grades 7-12. The connections to teaching we included in each lesson address both mathematical content and interpersonal interactions integral to teaching. 

The project has disseminated these materials through research publications and a network of mathematicians using Mathematical Association of America (MAA) conferences and online communities. In particular, 18 pilot testers and field testers received in-depth faculty development around implementing these materials; 5 of these testers are located at Hispanic-serving Institutions (HSIs) and 1 at a Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU); over 500 undergraduates used these materials; 135 additional faculty members accessed the materials by direct request to the project team. We anticipate the publication of the materials as a volume in the MAA Notes series before the end of 2022.

The developed materials fit (in a textbook independent way) into four standard mathematics major courses: abstract algebra, single variable calculus, discrete mathematics, and introductory statistics.The mathematics and statistics instructors who implemented our lessons found that the lessons fit well into their undergraduate curriculum, enriching their existing courses, and that the materials supported them in preparing prospective teachers. The applications to teaching we incorporated in each lesson provided them with concrete examples of undergraduate mathematics content that is foundational to teaching school mathematics. Further, the lesson annotations we included in the lessons supported their implementations and capacity to highlight connections to teaching during the lessons. Overall, the META Math annotated lesson plans gave instructors experience at incorporating applications to teaching into content courses, and some instructors expressed how they will continue to look for connections to teaching in other courses they teach and emphasize those connections more than they would have prior to participating in the study. 

The case study analysis leads us to conclude that the lesson plans provide the focus on connections to teaching that we intend. Prospective teachers who engaged with our lessons found it a valuable experience; from their perspective, they were provided with opportunities to work on mathematical problems through the lens of a secondary teacher and were given opportunities to see how the mathematics they are learning in college will help them when they teach school mathematics. 

We found that directly addressing connections to teaching in content courses has not detracted, in the eyes of undergraduates or of instructors, from the mathematical content that was learned by all undergraduates in the course. In fact, the focus on connections to teaching has led to some undergraduates self-reporting that they were pushed to think more deeply about the mathematical content. According to many of the undergraduates we interviewed, ?teaching is a universal skill,? and there?s no better way to learn the material than when you are asked to explain it to others and help guide their understanding. All undergraduates valued the applications to teaching because it made them think critically about a problem, it gave them opportunities to see multiple perspectives, it helped them understand errors other people make, it served as a warning to not make the same errors themselves, and it helped them communicate mathematical ideas. META Math lessons can enrich undergraduate mathematics courses by providing rich learning for all undergraduates while attending to the specific needs of prospective teachers.
